content.description: This is a fun, right-facing corner with great gear.  Stem, layback, jam your way up to a crux move as the corner leans right.  The corner pinches at this point for a move and then there is a great jam, pull around a small bulge on excellent holds, and you are home free.
content.protection: Small to medium cams, medium nuts, one big Camalot #3 or #3.5 works up high.  There are two bolts at the top, but they are for routes to the right and would leave you in a semi-hanging stance.  Better to build your anchor on top and find a comfortable seat for the belay.
content.location:
To reach Zanzibar, climb either

Ski Pole

or

Two Ears

(recommended) to the large ledge at the base of the dihedral (60m rope).

Two Ears

(5.7) starts right behind a large pine tree at the base and works up broken rock to a series of cracks (2 pins) and veers up and right after about 90 feet. Find the big ledge and Zanzibar is right above you.

Walk off to the west, somewhat steep and loose. After descending for a couple of hundred feet, keep an eye out for a small trail up through broken rock on your left. Go up and over a small shoulder and you will see your packs down by the big pine. You will pass beneath a couple of sport routes, including

Nickels and Dimes

, 8 bolts, 10c.

You can rap the route (and

Two Ears (aka The Fixed Pins Route?)

as a second rap) only if you bring two ropes, or are very careful with an 80m rope.

climbs.name: Two Ears (aka The Fixed Pins Route?)

content.description: Climb up and right past a small roof. End on slanting ledge.
content.protection: Plenty o' pro - a standard rack will do. There are bolted anchors at the top.
content.location:
Do a 2 rope rappel or keep going up

Zanzibar Dihedral

for the second pitch & walk off.

content.description:
Start 10 feet left of

Two Ears (aka The Fixed Pins Route?)

into a left-facing dihedral.  Step out onto the face at the hook in the crack.  Some runout up and right to more cracks two ledges below the upper face work well for anchoring.  The second pitch stays on the face between the dihedrals with many dirty variations.

I climbed just right of the dirty crack on the first pitch. Protection was scarce on some scary slab leading.
content.protection: Rack, nuts go in everywhere. Long runners are helpful
content.location:
10 feet left of

Two Ears (aka The Fixed Pins Route?)

in a left-facing dihedral.

content.description: Excellent steep slab climb on perfect granite. Start up the steepening slab to the first bolt and don't forget to breathe. Clear a small lip, take advantage of the big rest in the middle, and then levitate up the face. Distribute your weight thoughtfully and squeeze a tiny flaky hourglass to pull through the crux. Do NOT bail into the chossy corner to the right. Nice and long, so make sure to have two ropes if you want to get down. Otherwise, you'll be compelled to fire the 5.12 roof crack that looms above.
content.protection: 10 bolts to a nice ledge with bolt anchor and 75 pounds of chain. Perkins' guide says 8 bolts. Wrong!
content.location:
On left side of Weller Slab. Locate bolts about 60 feet left of

Two Ears

. 2 ropes for descent.

content.description:
Pie Direct is the direct start to the already fantastic

Apple Pie

. Most people climb the start of

Zanzibar Dihedral

and angle right to

Apple Pie

at the weakness 30 feet up. Some climb up

Zanzibar Dihedral

a bit and place a piece or two then climb down to the ledge to toprope the slab. Some just solo the 9 X slab just right of

Zanzibar Dihedral

. There is still plenty of room to do so. Instead, from the start of the base of the

Zanzibar Dihedral

, walk approximately 15 feet down and right on the wide ledge and identify the first bolt about 25 feet up. Do two easy mantels to reach the first bolt. Find your way to the second bolt, then, straight up to the

Apple Pie

finger crack.
content.protection:
2 bolts then lots of finger-sized gear for the

Apple Pie

crack.

climbs.name: Ultra Edge
climbs.fa: Harvey T. Carter & Tom Merrill, 1970. FFA: Carter, Pete Cleveland, Rozanne Cleveland, 1970. (from CGNA)?

content.description:
Ultra Edge has nice edge climbing. It is super exposed for some great views.

Climb the 1st pitch of

Zanzibar Dihedral

, then go right and climb the sharp edge to the top.
content.protection: This does not have the best protection available, although a standard rack should do. There is a bolted anchors at the top.
content.location:
It is located right of the 2nd pitch of

Zanzibar Dihedral

. Climb the right edge of Weller Slab. Walk off.

content.description:
This is a short but stellar Yosemite-style finger crack on upper Weller Slab. It splits the face between

Zanzibar Dihedral

and

Ultra Edge

. Climb the start of [[Zanzibar]105978828 and traverse right at a horizontal hand crack to the beginning of the finger crack. Alternatively, paddle directly up the unprotected 5.9 slab for 25 feet to the fingers section. Then enjoy the superb fingerlocks and fine friction of the clean face. Clear a small lip and, after the crack disappears, face climb up with occasional pro to the top.

Seems this climb is usually toproped by parties after climbing

Zanzibar

.
content.protection: Small cams, offset nuts, nothing bigger than 2". 2 bolt anchor at top of face, good for rapping, but more comfortable to belay off of tree about 10 feet back fro the edge. Bring some long slings.
content.location:
Climb

Two Ears

, move right, and begin 10 feet right of

Zanzibar Dihedral

. Rap the route, then rap

Two Ears

. If climbs are occupied, you can walk off down crappy eroded path to the west.

content.description: Start at a left-facing, crescent-shaped dihedral, and go up a slab to a belay stance. The first pitch is about 150'. The second pitch goes up from the belay stance into a large, left-facing dihedral. It continues along the dihedral until reaching a notch, the best part of the climb, where you climb out the dihedral onto a runout slab above. The second pitch is 160'.
content.protection: Small cams and stoppers, and a high tolerance for climbing through bushes. Build a belay at a ledge with a fixed pin. Do a second pitch, 5.8+, belay from a tree, and walk off from the top to the left.
content.location: Start kind of in the middle of the Weller Slab but a little left, at a left-facing, crescent-shaped dihedral.
